I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People's  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Sustainable  Rural  Infrastructure  Improvement 
Project.1 
 
2. 
The  project  will  reduce  poverty  and  raise  incomes  in  21  districts  of  northwest  and 
southwest Bangladesh by making social services and economic opportunities more accessible 
to rural people, including the poor women.2  

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3. 
In Bangladesh, rural infrastructure has considerably improved, enhancing the quality of 
life  of  rural  people.  Better  rural  infrastructure  has  fostered  balanced  development  of  rural 
economies through mutually reinforcing growth in the farm and non-farm sectors. The mobility of 
the rural poor has increased, and many are now availing themselves of health, education, and 
nongovernment services, as well as a wide range of economic opportunities. 

Empirical studies confirm that rural infrastructure development in Bangladesh has helped 
4. 
spur  economic  growth  and  reduce  poverty.  Recent  experience  has  shown  that  better  rural 
infrastructure leads to higher mobility of the rural poor and their farm products. It allows the poor 
greater access to providers of services, such as health and education, and to off-farm jobs. Rural 
infrastructure development also helps reduce rural poverty in the following ways: (i) effective road 
connectivity allows easier movement of labor; (ii) cost-effective transport of produce helps farmers 
realize  higher  farm  gate  prices;  (iii)  additional  traffic  volume  gives  rise  to  transport-related  small 
businesses, such as service stations, repair shops, food stalls, and guesthouses; (iv) construction 
of project facilities and after-construction maintenance directly generate jobs for the poor; and (v) 
poor women have greater access to economic opportunities and new jobs.  
 
 5. 
A study found that rural road investments in Bangladesh cut poverty significantly through 
increased  agricultural  production,  higher  wages,  lower  input  and  transportation  costs,  better 
educational  attainment,  and  higher  output  prices.3 Savings  in  household  transport  expenses 
averaged  36%–38%.  It  also  increased  output  indexes  by  30%–38%,  road  improvements 
increased  men’s  agricultural  wages  by  27%,  reduced  fertilizer  prices  by  about  5%,  and  raised 
aggregate crop price indexes by about 4%. Overall poverty incidence fell by about 1 percentage 
point, solely because of rural road improvements. A 1994 study showed that, in the catchment 
area  of  improved  facilities,  transport  charges  dropped  by  19%  for  cargo  and  23%  for 
passengers, while the volume traded in those markets doubled.4 Motorized traffic grew by 135% 
and other traffic increased by 85% after the roads were widened and paved. Another study on 

                                                 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  project  preparatory  technical  assistance.  ADB.  2009.  Technical 
Assistance to the People's Republic of Bangladesh for Preparing the Sustainable Rural Infrastructure Improvement 
Project. Manila. 

3   S.  Khandker,  Z.  Bakht,  and  G.  Koolwal.  The  Poverty  Impact  of  Rural  Roads:  Evidence  from  Bangladesh.  World 

Bank Policy Research Working Paper Series. No. 3875. April 2006.  

4  KfW. 1994. Socioeconomic Impact of Tangail Infrastructure Development Project. Dhaka. 

 

 

 2 

found 

in  Bangladesh 

that  accessible 

impact  of  rural 

infrastructure  development 

the 
transportation facilities had raised incomes of the poor profoundly.5  
 
6. 
Rural  infrastructure  development  continues  to  be  a  high  priority  for  the  Government  of 
Bangladesh  as  it  aims  to  improve  the  quality  of  life  of  rural  people.  The  framework  for 
investment in rural infrastructure includes (i) developing all-weather upazila (administrative unit- 
subdivision of a district) roads to provide access to and from growth center markets (GCMs), (ii) 
improving  union  and  village  roads  to  provide  rural  people  better  access  to  markets  and  social 
services,  and  (iii)  improving  the  infrastructure  of  GCMs  to  make  trading  more  efficient.  In  the 
National  Strategy  for  Accelerated  Poverty  Reduction  II,  the  government  emphasizes  rural 
infrastructure development with a focus on road connectivity.6 The goal is to link growth centers, 
union  parishad  (local  government  institution)  headquarters,  upazila  headquarters,  and  social 
service institutions such as schools and hospitals with the road networks.  
 
7. 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  supports  inclusive  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction  in  Bangladesh  through  the  strategic  priorities  identified  in  the  country  strategy  and 
program,  2006–2010.7 ADB’s  Strategy  20208 also  advocates  rural  infrastructure  development. 
Recognizing the importance of rural infrastructure for economic growth and poverty reduction in 
Bangladesh,  ADB  and  other  development  partners  including  KfW  have  supported  the 
government’s efforts to develop rural infrastructure through several projects. Initially focusing on 
building  rural  roads,  bridges,  culverts,  and  the  capacity  of  local  government  institutions,  ADB 
broadened its support to include the construction of GCMs, flood shelters, and union parishad 
offices. Subsequently gender considerations and community participation in rural infrastructure 
planning, implementation, and operations and maintenance were included.  
 
8. 
Despite improvements, rural infrastructure in the country remains underdeveloped. Only 
37%  of the rural  population  has  access to  all-weather  roads, compared with  60%  in  India  and 
61% in Pakistan. In South Asia, 57% of road networks are paved, while only 25% are paved in 
Bangladesh. This indicates poor road connectivity, higher vehicle operating costs, and the need 
for significant upgrading of rural infrastructure. The main problems in fostering road connectivity 
are  (i)  rapidly  growing  demand  for  road  transport  (6%  a  year),  (ii)  lack  of  funds  to  develop 
infrastructure, (iii)  lack  of  enforcement  of government’s  policies  and  regulations  in road  safety, 
(iv)  inadequate  maintenance  funding  (covering  only  40%  of  the  requirement),  and  (v)  lack  of 
technical  skills  and  capacity  building  of  local  government  institutions.  Women’s  access  to 
economic  opportunities  and  participation  in  decision-making  processes  of  local  governments 
remains limited. Bangladesh is considered one of the countries to be most affected by climate 
change.  Increased  risk  of  severe  flooding,  more  frequent  extreme  weather  events,  and  a 
potential rise in the sea level pose new challenges to rural infrastructure development.  
 
9. 
Realizing  the  full  growth  potential  of  rural  areas,  where  75%  of  the  total  population  and 
about 85% of the poor live, will require substantial improvement in rural infrastructure. Bangladesh 
has a large unmet demand for rural infrastructure improvement, and needs continuing—or even 
increasing—investment.  The  rural  road  network  is  284,781  kilometers  (km),  of  which  75% 
remains  unpaved.  The  Local  Government  Engineering  Department  (LGED)  is  planning  to 

                                                 
5   R. Ahmed and M. Hossain. 1990. Developmental Impact of Rural Infrastructure in Bangladesh. International Food 
Policy Research Institute in collaboration with Bangladesh Institute of Development Studies. Washington D.C.  

6  Government of Bangladesh, Planning Commission. 2009. Steps towards Change: National Strategy for     
   Accelerated Poverty Reduction II, FY2009–2011. Dhaka. 
7   ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program: Bangladesh, 2006–2010. Manila. 
8   ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  2008-2020. 

Manila. 

 

 develop  about  36,000  km  of  rural  roads  by  2025.  Rural  roads  require  1.77  million  meters  of 
bridges  and  culverts,  of  which  1.10  million  meters  have  been  developed.  By  2025,  240,000 
meters of bridges and culverts are planned to be developed. Of the 17,363 GCMs, only 2,895 
have been developed  with infrastructure facilities. By 2025, 4,500 GCMs are to be developed. 
LGED’s  20-year  road  master  plan  for  2005–2025  envisages  an  investment  of  $26  billion  to 
improve rural infrastructure.  
  
10. 
The Sustainable Rural Infrastructure Improvement Project will reduce poverty and raise 
incomes  in  21  districts  of  northwest  and  southwest  Bangladesh  by fostering  economic growth, 
capacity  development,  and  gender  equity.9 The  project  will  enhance  rural  people’s  access  to 
social  services,  such  as  health  and  education,  and  to  economic  opportunities.  Widening  the 
access  to  markets  and  livelihood  activities  will  increase  earnings  for  the  rural  poor,  including 
women. Based on the lessons learned from previous projects, project areas have been selected 
on the basis of high connectivity and poverty concentration. Fostering gender equity in economic 
opportunities,  ensuring  sustainable  operation  and  maintenance,  developing  climate-resilient 
infrastructure, and considering green elements in the design and implementation of the project 
will be emphasized more.  
  
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  reduced  poverty  in  intervention  areas.  The  key 
11. 
performance  target  will  be  population  in  project  areas  living  in  poverty  falling  by  6  percentage 
points  from  42.7%  in  2010.  The  project  outcome  will  be  widened  access  to  economic 
opportunities and social services for poor and women.  
 
C. 

Outputs 

12. 
The project outcome will be achieved through the following outputs: (i) road connectivity 
improved in a sustainable and climate-proof way; (ii) marketing facilities upgraded with specific 
provision for women; and (iii) rural infrastructure management, including climate-related issues, 
improved. 
 

1. 

Output 1: Road Connectivity Improved 

13. 
The project will upgrade 700 km of upazila roads and 100 km of union roads to bitumen-
surfaced standard to provide all-weather, sustainable, and climate-proof road connectivity from 
agricultural production areas and GCMs to other parts of the country. The greening of the roads 
will  be  mainstreamed  to  meet  aesthetic  recreational  needs,  reducing  the  surface  runoff  and 
checking  erosion  caused  by  heavy  rainfall  on  the  slope  of  the  embankment;  reducing  the 
encroachment  on  road  reserve  areas;  and  drought-proofing  with  measures  such  as  pasture 
development,  block  plantation,  and  horticulture  plantation.  The  roads  will  be  climate-proof  in 
response to the challenges of climate change. 

14.  With the participation of stakeholders, 94 roads have been selected for upgrading based 
on  length,  poverty  incidence,  and  degree  of  connectivity.  Cross-drainage  structures,  such  as 
bridges and culverts, with a total length of 3,270 meters will be built. Road safety features will be 
incorporated  into  the  design  of  upazila  roads.  These  may  include  road  signs,  delineators,  and 
bollards  near  the  approach  to  bridges;  reflectors  added  to  tree  trunks;  and  the  provision  of 

                                                 
9   The 21 districts are (i) Kushtia, Chuadanga, Meherpur, Jessore, Jhenidah, Narail, and Magura in Khulna Division; (ii) 
Rajshahi,  Natore,  Joypurhat,  Bogra,  Naogaon,  and  Chapai  Nawabgonj  in  Rajshahi  Division;  and  (iii)  Panchagarh, 
Thakurgaon, Nilphamari, Dinajpur, Rangpur, Gaibandha, Kurigram, and Lalmonirhat in Rangpur Division. 

3 

 

 loading and unloading zones. Women belonging to labor contracting societies10 will be engaged 
to improve road shoulders, embankment stabilization, planting of trees on roadsides, planting of 
shrubs on embankments, and other road maintenance works.  

2. 

Output 2: Marketing Facilities Upgraded with Specific Provision for Women 

15. 
Infrastructure  of  92  GCMs  will  be  improved  with  sections  for  women  in  50  markets.  A 
participatory approach will be used to identify the GCM where market sections for women will be 
built.  Each market  will  be  connected  to  either  an  existing  paved  road  or to  one  of those to  be 
upgraded  under  the  project.  The  markets  will  be  provided  with  paved  trading  areas,  sheds, 
improved  water  supply  system,  adequate  drainage  facilities,  sanitation  facilities,  and  market 
offices. At each GCM, a market management committee will be responsible for ensuring proper 
physical  and  financial  maintenance.  In  each  GCM,  6–12  shops  will  be  built  solely  for  women 
traders based on demand shown during participatory discussions.  

16. 
Three GCMs have been selected for piloting the introduction of rural piped water supply 
(one each in the divisions of Khulna, Rajshahi, and Rangpur). The goal is to find a sustainable 
management  model  under  which  the  community  and  local  government  can  operate  and 
maintain  piped  water  supply  in  rural  markets  where the  availability  of  safe  water  is  a  problem. 
The  community  will  be  engaged  to  participate  in  planning,  construction,  and  operation  and 
maintenance of this mini piped water supply system. 

17. 
Three GCMs have been selected for piloting the introduction of renewable energy supply 
(one  each  in  the  divisions  of  Khulna,  Rajshahi,  and  Rangpur).  In  the  selected  GCMs,  no 
electricity  is  available  and  the  Rural  Electrification  Board  has  no  plans  to  provide  electricity 
soon.  The  shops  (including  the  market  sections  for  women),  toilets,  and  street  lights  will  be 
electrified using solar-powered photovoltaic cells. The beneficiaries will be trained on judicious 
use and maintenance of the system, and the responsibility of maintaining the system by paying 
the maintenance charges.  
 

3. 

Output 3: Rural Infrastructure Management Improved  

18. 
The project will upgrade the capacity of LGED and other local government institutions to 
manage  rural  infrastructure.  For  LGED,  the  institutional  capacity  of  the  staff  will  be  improved 
through training programs in (i) financial management, (ii) participatory planning, (iii) construction 
supervision,  (iv)  sustainable  maintenance  and  management,  (v)  planning  and  implementation  of 
climate-resilient infrastructure (based on a climate vulnerability mapping), (vi) quality control, (vii) 
information  technology,  (viii)  gender  and  development,  and  (ix)  monitoring  and  evaluation.  The 
training  program  for  officials  of  local  government  institutions  will  include  union  parishad 
chairpersons, members, and upazila officials, and members of the management committees of 
GCMs. The program will cover the roles and responsibilities of local governments, sustainable 
road  maintenance,  financial  management,  poor  and  indigenous  people’s  participation  in  local 
decision making, and participatory planning. The training program will be supplemented by on-
the-job training and awareness campaigns for key target groups on road safety, climate change, 
and environmental issues.  
 
19. 
Incentive-based  infrastructure.  20  union  parishads  will  have  access  to  funds  for 
infrastructure  development,  if  they  can  meet  the  performance  standards  related  to  women’s 
participation in local governments. For this purpose, $1 million will be set aside to use with pilot 
participants  for  additional  infrastructure  investments  if  the  performance  criteria  are  met.  The 
                                                 
10 These societies comprise poor women with limited income-earning capabilities who carry out routine maintenance 

on rural roads using basic hand tools and materials supplied by LGED. 

4 

 

 union parishads in the pilot that meet the agreed performance standards will receive funds of up 
to $45,000 each for infrastructure activities, such as upgrading village roads, building bridges or 
culverts,  upgrading  rural  market  structures,  and  installing  solar  panels  to  provide  lighting  for  a 
rural market. The  union parishads  will  manage the  infrastructure  investment  with  the technical 
support from LGED.  

20.    Sustainable  road  maintenance  system.  The  project  will  pilot  sustainable  road 
maintenance  in  three  roads  with  high  traffic  volumes  (one  in  each  division)  and  prepare  a 
sustainable road maintenance plan. The detailed procedures and implementation guidelines of 
the  piloting  process  of  collecting  road  user  charges  will  be  prepared,  taking  into  consideration 
the  stakeholders'  opinions  and  the  necessary  administrative  and  procedural  approval from the 
government. 
  
21. 
Climate-change-resilient  infrastructure.  The  project  will  mainstream  climate  risk 
reduction  into  policy  formulation  and  infrastructure  development.  A  key  feature  is  climate-
proofing and disaster-resilient designs for rural infrastructure to ensure that upgraded roads are 
less vulnerable to floods, storm surge, landslides, and impacts of other extreme weather events. 
The main activities include preparing a climate-change-resilient infrastructure management plan, 
mapping  climate  vulnerability  of  the  rural  areas  (with  a  focus  on  the  project  areas),  and 
designing  and  introducing  adaptation  strategies  for  roads  to  improve  flood  and  drought 
management.  

D. 

Investment and Financing Plans  

The project is estimated to cost $108.4 million (Table 1).

Implementation Arrangements 

25. 
The executing agency will be LGED in the Local Government Division of the Ministry of 
Local  Government,  Rural  Development,  and  Cooperatives.  A  project  steering  committee  will 
provide  policy  guidance  for  project  implementation.11 The  committee  will  meet  twice  a  year  to 
review  the  progress  of  project  implementation.  A  suitably  staffed  project  management  office 
(PMO), to be established by LGED at its headquarters in Dhaka, will implement the project. The 
chief  engineer  of  LGED,  assisted  by  the  project  monitoring  and  evaluation  unit,  will  be 
responsible for project implementation and coordination. The PMO will have one office in each 
of  the  three  divisions.  A  project  director  in  the  Dhaka  headquarters  and  one  deputy  project 
director  in  each  regional  office  will  be  responsible  for  the  day-to-day  implementation  and 
supervision  of  project  activities.  The  PMO  will  be  assisted  by  consultants  with  expertise  in 
engineering  design  and  supervision,  economics  and  finance,  social  and  gender  development, 
participatory  approaches,  environmental  and  climate  assessment,  monitoring  and  evaluation, 
and  local  governance.  The  LGED  district  offices,  headed  by  executive  engineers,  will  be 
responsible for implementing subprojects under the guidance of the PMO.  
 
In addition to their technical and economic viability, the subprojects (94 rural roads and 92 
26. 
rural markets) included in the project were prioritized based on social indicators, such as poverty, 
gender  disparity,  environmental  conditions,  requirements  for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement, 
and connectivity to markets and higher-order roads. 12 During project implementation, the design 
and  supervision  consultants  will  prepare  comprehensive  and  detailed  subproject  appraisal 
reports by district.  
 
27. 
the project administration manual.13 

The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

28. 
A  TA  to  support  LGED  in  institutionalizing  women’s  benefits  from  rural  infrastructure 
initiatives is being prepared. The TA will have two components: (i) developing an agreed set of 
elements of women’s participation in the decision making and planning of local governments on 
rural  infrastructure,  and (ii)  piloting  a  performance-based  approach to  women’s  participation  in 
local  governments.  The  local  governments  in  the  pilot  that  meet  the  agreed  performance 
standards, which the TA will develop, will receive funds from the project for rural infrastructure 
development.  The  TA  will  support  the  implementation  of  LGED’s  Gender  Equity  Action  Plan, 
2008–2015  by  developing  a  more  standardized  approach  to  ensure  that  women  participate  in 
and benefit from rural infrastructure development. ADB will recruit individual consultants for the 
TA following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Economic and Financial 

Economic  analyses  indicate  that  the  project  is  economically  viable.  The  project  will 
29. 
generate two types of benefits: (i) the direct benefits, accruing from savings in vehicle operating 
costs,  reduction  in  travel  time,  enhanced  marketing  facilities,  and  commercialization  of 

7 

 

 productive  activities;  and  (ii)  the  indirect  benefits,  stemming from  positive  externalities  that  are 
not quantified in the economic evaluation, but are likely to be significant. The project will bring 
institutional  development  in  the  project  areas,  which  will  promote  the  equitable  distribution  of 
economic and non-economic benefits. The major components (36 roads and 15 markets) were 
evaluated. The estimated economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for rural roads varies between 
16%  and  46%.  The  EIRR  for  GCMs  is  estimated  between  16%  and  37%.  The  sensitivity 
analysis with adverse variation in project costs and project benefits also indicates that evaluated 
roads  and  markets  have  EIRRs  well  above  12%  even  with  increased  costs  and  reduced 
benefits. 
  
B. 

Governance 

LGED’s  financial  management  system  was  assessed  to  ensure  that  its  financial 
30. 
management and procurement capacity is adequate to implement the project. The project has 
established  clear  input  and  output  targets  to  ensure  good  governance,  accountability,  and 
transparency.  The  design  and  implementation  arrangements  aim  to  mitigate  corruption  risks. 
Risks  associated  with  project  management,  including  procurement  and  disbursement,  will  be 
mitigated  by  (i)  engaging  international  and  national  consultants  to  advise  and  assist  in  the 
procurement  of  goods  and  services;  (ii)  requiring  that  civil  work  contracts  include  a  condition 
that contractors adhere to ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, amended, from time to time); (iii) 
the  PMO  periodically  inspecting  the  contractor’s  fund  withdrawals  and  settlements;  and  (iv) 
reporting  on  project  activities  and  implementation  on  the  LGED  website to foster transparency 
and timely awarding of contracts. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy  was explained to and discussed 
with the government and LGED. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the project administration manual. 

 
Poverty and Social 

C. 

The  project  will  help  reduce  poverty  by  6  percentage  points from  42.7% in  2010  in  the 
31. 
intervention areas. Under the project, 4.2 million people will gain all-weather access to markets 
and  social  services.  In  addition,  an  estimated  28,500  person-years  of  unskilled  jobs  will  be 
created during construction (30% of which  will be for women); and 3,600 person-years of jobs 
for poor women will be created in road maintenance, and roadside tree planting and care. Farm 
income will rise 49%—due to 15%  higher crop yields and a 45% increase in the availability of 
agricultural  inputs—which  will  reduce  poverty  in  project  areas.  Improved  capacity  of  the  local 
governments in running their affairs in a participatory manner will benefit and empower the poor, 
especially women.  
  
Gender and development. Implementation of a gender action plan will help ensure that 
32. 
women  participate 
in 
infrastructure planning and implementation will enable them to voice their needs and participate 
in decision making. New jobs will be created for women in construction and maintenance, and 
elements of the core labor standards will be enforced to benefit them. Constructing sections for 
women in 50 markets with about 500 shops will create business opportunities and jobs for poor 
women. Skills development and other training of beneficiaries and union parishad members will 
help  in raising the  return  on  women’s  labor,  enabling them  to  influence decision  making.  Over 
the long-run, activities addressing women’s empowerment will help to narrow the gender gap in 
the project areas. 
  

infrastructure.  Women’s 

in  and  benefit 

involvement 

from  rural 

8 

 

 D. 

Safeguards 

33. 
Environment. The project is category B for environment. An environmental assessment 
and review framework and an initial environmental examination for core subprojects have been 
prepared. Since the project will improve the existing rural road network and new roads are not 
planned,  adverse  environmental 
impacts  are  not  expected.  The  potential  problematic 
environmental issues during construction include (i) soil erosion, silt runoff, and gully erosion; (ii) 
drainage  blockage  and/or  congestion,  waterlogging,  and  localized  flooding;  (iii)  surface  water 
and  groundwater  contamination;  (iv)  air  (dust)  and  noise  pollution;  (v)  contamination  from 
storage and transportation of construction materials; and (vi) hygiene, sanitation, and safety of 
construction workers. These effects were considered during project design and measures were 
included  to  minimize  possible  harm,  as  shown  in  the  environmental  management  plan,  which 
will be a part of the construction contracts.  
 
34. 
Resettlement.  The  project  is  category  B  for  involuntary  resettlement.  However,  since 
the  scope  includes  only  upgrading  and  sealing  of  upazila  and  union  roads  on  their  existing 
alignments, as well as upgrading GCM facilities, the project will not involve relocation and very 
little,  if  any,  land  acquisition.  Because  the  roads  are  in  rural  areas,  there  has  not  been  any 
encroachment  onto  the  right-of-way.  If  small  strips  of  land  are  required  to  facilitate  shape 
corrections,  a  settlement  will  be  negotiated.  A  resettlement  framework  has  been  prepared  for 
the  project,  which  outlines  the  due  diligence  methodology  for  transparent  implementation  of  a 
negotiated  settlement,  and 
for  preparation  of  a  resettlement  plan  and 
implementation responsibility. 
 
Indigenous  people.    The  project  is  category  B  for  indigenous  people.  Indigenous 
35. 
people make up less than 2% of the population of the project districts, and their livelihoods are 
similar  to  those  of  the  majority  population.  However,  indigenous  people  are  generally  poorer 
than  the  majority  with  less  access  to  land  and  resources,  and  lower  educational  attainment. 
Other  social  differences,  such  as  religion  and  gender  relations,  also  necessitate  separate 
consideration of participation methods. Overall, the impacts from better road and market access 
will  be  positive.  An  indigenous  peoples  framework  has  been  developed  that  summarizes  the 
results  of  consultations  with  the  indigenous  people  and  lays  out  initial  strategies  for  ensuring 
that they participate in and benefit from the project. The project provides for the development of 
indigenous peoples plans for upazilas where their communities are prevalent.  
 
E. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

triggers 

the 

36. 
The  project  involves  some  risks,  which  are  manageable  and  will  be  largely  mitigated 
during  implementation.  Major  risks  and  mitigating  measures  are  summarized  in  Table  4  and 
described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.14 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Risks 
Implementation delays 

Consequences of climate 
change  

Mitigating Measures 
Potential  delays  in  project  start-up  will  be  reduced  by  taking  advance  action  on 
contracting  of  civil  works  and  consulting  services.  Some  contractors’  limited 
experience  in  implementing  foreign-aided  projects  will  be  remedied  by  their 
participation in training programs under the project.  
The  project  will  mainstream  climate  risk  reduction  into  policy  formulation  and 
infrastructure  development.  Key  features  are  climate-proofing  and  disaster-
resilient  designs  for  rural  infrastructure,  and  preparation  of  a  climate-change-

                                                 
14 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

9 

 

 resilient  infrastructure management  plan,  and a climate  vulnerability mapping of 
project areas.   

Lack of maintenance funds   The government agreed to reduce the gap between annual budgetary allocation 
and needs for operation and maintenance. The project will also pilot sustainable 
road  maintenance  in  three  high-traffic-volume  roads,  and  prepare  a  sustainable 
road maintenance plan 

  Source: Asian Development Bank. 

V. 

ASSURANCES  

The government and LGED have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
37. 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in  the  project  administration  manual  and  loan  documents.  The  government  and  LGED  have 
agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement.  
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
38. 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various 
currencies  equivalent  to  SDR38,271,000  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the 
Sustainable Rural Infrastructure Improvement Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with 
an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum 
thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and 
conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
 

 Haruhiko Kuroda 

   

President 

21 October 2010
